Focusing on promoting diversity and addressing systemic racism is not about discriminating against any individual or group, nor is it about suggesting that any group is superior or inferior to another.

The reality is, however, that certain groups in our society have had historical and ongoing advantages while others have had considerable and lasting disadvantages. Systemic racism is a problem that has created vast disparities in education, healthcare, housing, employment, and wealth that have impacted individuals and entire communities. Addressing these systemic issues will serve to help promote a more just and equitable society that will ultimately benefit everyone.

Affirmative action and other steps that involve targeting groups that have been historically marginalized (such as Black, Indigenous, and minority groups) are one way of trying to address these imbalances, but these policies are not designed to discriminate against anyone. Instead, the aim is to level the playing field by promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion for all.

In conclusion, promoting diversity and addressing systemic racism does not promote discrimination against any particular group; instead, the aim is to promote a more equitable society for everyone by addressing the historical and ongoing disparities that have impacted certain groups more severely. All individuals, regardless of their race, should have equal access to opportunity and inclusion, and we must all work together to make this a reality.
